Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: A heated dispute has escalated to the point where they are questioning staying together.
Story: My phone buzzes in my hand, the screen lighting up with “Mom” just as my girlfriend’s voice cracks, her eyes red from arguing. We’ve been at it for hours, voices rising and falling, neither of us willing to back down. She’s waiting for me to say something, to fix this, to prove that I care enough to fight for us. But the phone keeps ringing. It’s Sunday—my parents expect my call, the one I never miss, where I tell them about my week and ask about Dad’s new hobby or Mom’s garden. I can almost hear my mother’s gentle voice, her disappointment if I don’t call. My girlfriend’s arms are crossed, her jaw set, and I know if I turn away now, it’ll only make things worse. My chest tightens, torn between the comfort of my parents’ familiar love and the urgent, fragile tension in the room. I want to be a good son, but I also want to be the boyfriend she needs right now. The phone keeps ringing, and I’m frozen, caught between two worlds, unable to move.
